snippet: Rich and poor mostly must buy the same sort of plan, even though income affects how much health care you might be willing to pay for....
abstract: The Upshot; one-size-fits-all health insurance policies, which are common in employer-sponsored health plans, disproportionately burden low-wage workers; such policies have even more far-reaching negative affects, yet efforts to reform them are contentious and face significant political opposition.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS BAGLEY and AUSTIN FRAKT
byline.contributor: Nicholas Bagley is a professor at the University of Michigan law school. You can follow him on Twitter at @nicholas_bagley. Austin Frakt is a health economist with several governmental and academic affiliations. He blogs at The Incidental Economist, and you can follow him on Twitter at @afrakt.

lead_paragraph: Rich and poor mostly must buy the same sort of plan, even though income affects how much health care you might be willing to pay for.

headline.main: The Problem With One-Size-Fits-All Health Insurance
